awd_titl_txt: Developmental Emergence of math-Gender Stereotypes and Math Self-Concepts
awd_abstract_narration:
The underrepresentation of women in STEM disciplines is a societal problem with economic implications. Despite the narrowing of the gap in math performance between boys and girls in the past two decades, gender disparities still influence students' decisions to enter math-related careers. Young students' math self-concepts have been found to predict future choices in math-related domains. As early as elementary school--and in the absence of gender differences in math achievement--girls have lower math self-concepts than boys. Developmental scientists examining the factors implicated in women's underrepresentation in STEM distinguish two interrelated constructs. The first is the child's belief about the link between math and gender (i.e., a belief about a social group and "who does math"), which can be called a math-gender stereotype. The second is how strongly children link themselves to math (i.e., whether a child "identifies with math"), which can be called a math self-concept. This proposal is funded by the EHR Core Research program, which supports fundamental research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. 

This project will examine the development of math-gender stereotypes (Experiment 1), math self-concepts (Experiment 2), and their consequences for math motivation and career interest (Experiment 3). In experiment 1, using a cross-sectional approach, the researchers will examine the developmental emergence of the pervasive U.S. stereotype that math is "for males" in elementary school. In Experiment 2, focus will be on the emergence of how strongly boys and girls associate themselves with math (math self-concept) and possible gender differences in this developmental pathway. In Experiment 3, the project team will verify the developmental order using a fine-grained longitudinal approach, and trace the consequences for elementary school boys' and girls' motivation for math and their future career interest in STEM. Taken together, Experiments 1 through 3 will deepen understanding about when and how math stereotypes and self-concepts emerge in young children, with direct implications for the design of novel interventions aimed at reducing math stereotyping and strengthening math self-concepts.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to explore when children's attitudes and beliefs about math and themselves develop. When do gender stereotypes and other attitudes and beliefs about math form and how do they impact children's confidence, interest, and ability in math? To answer these questions, we worked closely with a large northwest science museum, several Seattle-area school districts and community organizations, as well as international institutions of higher education in Chile, Croatia, and Spain to design a series of studies that was culturally sensitive with results that would be broadly applicable.

This project made several contributions to the fields of developmental, educational, and social psychology, particularly in the study of children's unconscious or "implicit" attitudes and beliefs. One major finding from our research showed that children already start to develop beliefs about "who does math" (the stereotype that math = boys) as early as 5 years of age. In order to deepen our understanding about how children's attitudes and beliefs about math relate to their actual math achievement, our project also showed that children's positive math attitudes (math = good) and math self-concepts (math = me) related to better math achievement in children from Grades 1 and 5.

Finally, we developed new intervention approach to strengthen children's beliefs that they can do math ("math self-concepts") in Grade 3. In one group of children, we assessed their math self-concepts before and after running the interventions and found that children identified with math more strongly afterwards. We also assessed math self-concepts in another group of children who did not do the interventions, and their math self-concepts did not change, suggesting that the interventions were responsible for the stronger math self-concepts in the first group. Future work will improve these interventions further and test them with larger groups of children.

Beyond the laboratory studies, we also investigated whether parental beliefs and home math practices influence children. One study showed that how children think of themselves in relation to math is related to their parent's attitudes and beliefs about math. Children's beliefs, in turn, influenced their math performance in school. In this way, we are beginning to articulate how parental beliefs can influence children's achievement in school.

In another study, we found that girls' beliefs about math were strongly related to how their fathers interact with them around math. When fathers talked about and did math with their daughters, it influenced their daughters' emerging sense of math identity.

The work described above was done in collaborations with universities in three other countries: Chile, Croatia, and Spain. We formed an international network of researchers (a) so we could broaden the scope and generalizability of our empirical work, and (b) to expand the diversity among the participating children. The fact that these results come from different parts of the world enables us to draw inferences about cultural diversity and universality, which inform psychological theory.

The project was also dedicated to increasing access to research and disseminating results more widely. We partnered with Pacific Science Center in Seattle to create a remote laboratory at the museum where any family could learn from scientists and participate in our studies. We also produced new online versions of our research tools so that future studies can greatly increase the diversity of our participants; they will not be limited just to families or schools near the researchers. Finally, we created a freely available, interactive module designed for the general public to learn more about how children's sense of self can affect their academic learning, thus linking science and impact.
